Book1.Title: The Screwtape Letters
Book1.Author: C.S.Lewis
Book1.Quote: It is funny how mortals always picture us as putting things into their minds: in reality our best work is done by keeping things out.

Book2.Title: Submission
Book2.Author: Michel Houellebecq
Book2.Quote: It may well be impossible for people who have lived and prospered under a given social system to imagine the point of view of those who feel it offers them nothing, and who can contemplate its destruction without any particular dismay.

Book3.Title: Notes From Underground
Book3.Author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky
Book3.Quote: Man only likes to count his troubles; he doesn't calculate his happiness

Book4.Title: The Strange Death of Europe
Book4.Author: Douglas Murray
Book4.Quote: To immerse oneself in popular culture for any length of time is to wallow in an almost unbearable shallowness. Was the sum of European endeavour and achievement really meant to culminate in this

Book5.Title: All Quiet on the Western Front
Book5.Author: Maria Erich Remarque
Book5.Quote: I am young, I am twenty years old; yet I know nothing of life but despair, death, fear, and fatuous superficiality cast over an abyss of sorrow. I see how peoples are set against one another, and in silence, unknowingly, foolishly, obediently, innocently slay one another.

Book6.Title: Stoner
Book6.Author: John Williams
Book6.Quote: He was forty-two years old, and he could see nothing before him that he wished to enjoy and little behind him that he cared to remember.

Book7.Title: The Road to Wigan Pier
Book7.Author: George Orwell
Book7.Quote: It is only when you meet someone of a different culture from yourself that you begin to realise what your own beliefs really are.

Book8.Title: The Gulag Archipelago 1918-1956
Book8.Author: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn
Book8.Quote: in order to do evil, must first believe that what they are doing is good, otherwise they can't do it

Book9.Title: The Master and Margarita
Book9.Author: Mikhail Bulgakov
Book9.Quote: But what can be done, the one who loves must share the fate of the one he loves.

Book10.Title: The Third Policeman
Book10.Author: Flann O'Brian
Book10.Quote: 'Your talk I' said, 'is surely the handiwork of wisdom because not one word of it do I understand'

Book11.Title: The Complete Cosmicomics
Book11.Author: Italo Calvino
Book11.Quote: time is a catastrophe, perpetual and irreversible.

Book12.Title: The Narrow Road to The Deep North
Book12.Author: Richard Flanagan
Book12.Quote: In trying to escape the fatality of memory, he discovered with an immense sadness that pursuing the past inevitably only leads to greater loss.
